intro: Adenophora triphylla var. tetraphylla, commonly known as the four-leaf bluebell, is a flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It is a member of the Campanulaceae family, characterized by its bell-shaped flowers and perennial growth habit. The plant typically grows in moist, wooded areas and thrives in partial to full shade. Its leaves are opposite, lance-shaped, and often have a bluish-green hue. The four-leaf form is a rare variation, making it a sought-after species in botanical collections.
